tuv.seg: What is the euro?
Céard é an Euro?
The euro is the single currency used in 18 EU member states, including Ireland
Is aonad amháin airgeadais é an euro a mbaintear úsáid as i 18 de bhaill stáit an AE, Éire san áireamh

(The 18 countries in the Euro area are: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, L:atvia, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia and Spain). Lithuania will adopt the euro as its official currency on 1 January 2015

(Is iad na 17 tír i limistéar an Euro ná: An Ostair, An Bheilg, An Chipir, Éire, An Eastóin, An Fhionlainn, An Fhrainc, An Ghréig, An Ghearmáin, An Iodáil, An Laitvia, Lucsamburg, An Ísiltír, Málta, An Phortaingéil, An tSóivéin, Poblacht na Slóvaice agus An Spáinn

The euro came into being in cashless form on 1 January 1999 when 12 of these member states formed an Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) and permanently locked the exchange rates of their currencies against the euro

Tháinig an euro i bhfeidhm, i chuile fhoirm ach i nótaí agus boinn, ar an 1 Eanáir 1999 nuair a rinne na baill stáit sin Aontas Eacnamúil agus Airgeadais (AEA) agus nuair a shochraigh siad go buan an ráta malairte idir a gcuid airgid féin agus an Euro
Euro notes and coins were put into circulation in 12 of these EU states on 1 January 2002
Cuireadh nótaí agus boinn Euro ar fáil sna 12 stáit den AE ar 1 Eanáir 2002
(Slovenia joined the euro zone in January 2007
(Chuaigh an tSlóivéin sa limistéar an euro in Eanáir 2007
Malta and Cyprus adopted the euro on 1 January 2008
Glac Málta agus An Chipir an euro an 1 Eanáir 2008
Slovakia adopted the euro in January 2009 and Estonia joined in January 2011)
Glac Poblacht na Slóvaice an euro in Eanáir 2009 agus An Eastóin in Éanair 2011.)
Exchanging Irish banknotes and coin
Nótaí bainc agus boinn Éireannacha a mhalartú
The Central Bank of Ireland will exchange all Irish banknotes and coins for euro indefinitely (this means for many years to come)
Déanfaidh Banc Ceannais na hÉireann malartú idir nótaí bainc agus boinn Éireannacha agus an euro gan ceapadh lae (is é sin le blianta amach romhainn)
If you call into the Central Bank, banknotes to the value of £3,000 (€3,800) per transaction can be exchanged
Má bhuaileann tú isteach ag an mBanc Ceannais, is féidir malartú a dhéanamh ar nótaí bainc suas go £3,000 (€3,800) an bhirt
If you wish to exchange more than £3,000, the value in euro will be forwarded to you as a cheque through the post
Má tá tú ag iarraidh níos mó ná £3,000 a mhalartú do euro, cuirfear an luach i euro chugat i bhfoirm seic sa phost
If you wish to exchange Irish coins, values up to £500 (€635) can be exchanged immediately
Má tá tú ag iarraidh boinn Éireannacha a mhalartú le euro, is féidir luachanna suas go £500 (€635) a mhalartú ar an bpointe
If you have more than £500 in coins, the euro value will be forwarded to you as a cheque through the post
Má tá níos mó ná £500 i bhfoirm bonn, cuirfear an luach i euro chugat i bhfoirm seic sa phost
(All coins must be separated by denomination and presented in coin bags)
(Ní mór na boinn ar fad a scaradh de réir ainmníochta agus a chur isteach i málaí boinn)
You can call into the Central Bank or you can send Irish banknotes to the Central Bank by registered post and you will receive their value in euro by cheque
Mar rogha ar sin, is féidir leat nótaí bainc Éireannacha a sheoladh chuig an Banc Ceannais ach úsáid a bhaint as post cláraithe agus gheobhaidh tú a luach i euro i bhfoirm seic
(See address under 'Where to apply')
(Féach seoladh faoi ‘Cá háit a ndéanfar iarratas’)
Exchanging euro-area banknotes and coins
Nótaí bainc agus boinn an limistéir Euro a mhalartú
If you have banknotes from a holiday or trip to another EU country that is now part of the euro area it is still possible to exchange these banknotes for euro
Má tá nótaí bainc as tír eile an AE atá anois ina cuid de limistéar an euro fós agat tá tú fós in ann na nótaí bainc seo a mhalartú do euro
In order to exchange this currency, you will need to send the notes to the national central banks of the relevant country
Chun an t-airgeadra seo a mhalartú, beidh ort na nótaí a sheoladh chuig banc ceannais náisiúnta na tíre cuí
Details of your name and address and, if applicable, your bank account details should be included with the bank notes
Ba cheart duit d’ainm agus do sheoladh agus sonraí do chuntas bainc más gá a chur isteach leis na nótaí bainc
(You should be aware that the postage cost of sending the bank notes might exceed their euro value)
(Ba cheart duit a thabhairt faoi deara gur féidir le costas an phoist a bheith níos mó ná luach euro na nótaí bainc)
There is no means of exchanging foreign coin other than by travelling to the country in question and exchanging it at that country's national central bank
Níl bealach ar bith chun boinn eachtracha a mhalartú ach trí cuairt a thabhart ar an tír atá i gceist agus iad a mhalartú i mbanc ceannais náisiúnta na tíre sin
Countries in the euro area
Na Tíortha i limistéar an euro

The 18 countries in the euro area (also known as the eurozone) are: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia and Spain

Is iad na 18 tír i limistéar an euro ná: An Ostair, An Bheilg, An Chipir, Éire, An Eastóin, An Fhionlainn, An Fhrainc, An Ghearmáin, An Iodáil, An Laitvia, Lucsamburg, An Ísiltír, Málta, An Phortaingéil, Poblacht na Slóvaice, An tSóivéin, An Spáinn, agus an Ghréig
The United Kingdom (UK) decided not to participate
Tá cinneadh tógtha ag an Ríocht Aontaithe (RA) gan páirt a ghlacadh sa euro ach tá sé tugtha le fios acu go bhfuil seans ann go mbeidh siad ag smaoineadh ar pháirt a ghlacadh ann níos deanaí
Euro notes and coins were first put into circulation on 1 January 2002
Cuireadh nótaí agus boinn Euro ar fáil ar an 1 Eanáir 2002
The euro is part of the process of EMU
Cuid de phroiséas an AEA é an euro
EMU is provided for in the Maastricht Treaty, which the people of Ireland endorsed by referendum in June 1992
Tá na rialacha a bhaineann le AEA leagtha síos i gConradh Maastricht, a tháinig i bhfeidhm in Éirinn tar éis do phobal na tíre glacadh leis i reifreann i mí an Mheithimh 1992
As well as the euro, EMU has involved the creation of an independent European Central Bank (ECB)
Chomh maith leis an Euro tá Banc Ceannais na hEorpa (BCE) neamhspléach cruthaithe ag AEA
The euro is used also in Andorra, Monaco, San Marino and Vatican City
Baintear úsáid as an euro chomh maith in Andóra, Monacó, San Mairíne agus Cathair na Vatacáine

Several overseas territories of the 167 euro area countries use the euro: these include the Canaries, Madeira, the Azores and the French Outre-Mer territories (Guyana, Martinique, Guadeloupe, Reunion and the collective territories of Mayotte and St Pierre and Miquelon)

Baineann críocha thar lear ar leith de chuid na 17 tír i limistéar an euro úsáid as an euro; san áireamh tá Na hOileáin Chanáracha, Maidéara, na hAsóir, agus Críocha Outre-Mer na Fraince (Gúain na Fraince, Martinique, Guadalúip, Réunion agus comhchríocha Mayotte agus St Pierre agus Miquelon)
How was the euro introduced?
Cén chaoi ar tugadh isteach an Euro?
On 1 January 1999, the exchange rates of the countries joining EMU were permanently locked against the Euro
Ar an 1 Eanáir 1999, socraíodh rátaí malairte airgeadais na dtíortha san AEA go buan i gcoinne an Euro
In Ireland the euro is worth £0.787564 or just under 79 pence
In Éirinn is fiú £0.787564 an euro nó díreach beagainín níos lú ná 79 pingin
The period between 1 January 1999 and 31 December 2001 was known as the transition period
Tugtar an t-idirthréimhse ar an tréimhse idir 1 Eanáir 1999 agus 31 Nollaig 2001
On 1 January 2002, euro notes and coins were put into circulation and the withdrawal of national notes and coins began
Ar an 1 Eanáir 2002 cuireadh nótaí agus boinn euro ar fáil agus cuireadh tús le nótaí agus boinn náisiúnta a tharraingt siar
From 9 February 2002, the Irish pound was no longer accepted for transactions
Ón 9ú Feabhra 2002 ní raibh duine in ann úsáid a bhaint as an bpunt Éireannach a thuilleadh
The euro changeover in Ireland was complete by 1 July 2002
Bhí an t-athrú iomlán curtha i gcrích faoin 1 Iúil 2002
Euro notes and coins
Nótaí agus boinn Euro
• There are 7 euro banknotes, in denominations of €5, €10, €20, €50, €100, €200 and €500
• Tá 7 gcinn de nótaí bainc euro ann, nótaí de €5, €10, €20, €50, €100, €200 agus €500
• There are 8 euro coins, in denominations of 1, 2, 5, 10, 20 and 50 cent and €1 and €2
• Tá 8 gcinn de bhoinn euro ann, boinn de 1, 2, 5, 10, 20 agus 50 ceint agus €1 agus €2
There are 100 cent to the euro
Céad ceint atá sa Euro
• The smallest of the euro coins (the 1 cent coin) is slightly smaller than the old Irish 5p coin and the largest (2 euro coin) is about the same size as the old Irish 2p coin
• Tá an bonn is lú Euro (bonn ceint amháin) beagainín níos lú ná an seanphíosa 5p a bhí againn agus an ceann is mó (bonn dhá Euro) a bheag nó a mhór ar an méid céanna leis an seanbhonn 2p Éireannach
• One side of the euro coins is the same in all euro area member states
• Tá taobh amháin de na boinn Euro díreach mar an gcéanna sna baill stáit uilig
The other side shows the 12 stars of the EU flag, the year and a national emblem
Ar an taobh eile tá dhá réalt déag bhratach na hEorpa, an bhliain agus suaitheantais náisiúnta
In Ireland, the national emblem is the harp and the word Eire
In Éirinn baintear úsáid as an gclairseach mar shuaitheantais náisiúnta leis an bhfocal Éire
Converting from Irish pounds to euro
Puint Éireannacha a mhalartú go Euro
The conversion rate between the euro and the Irish pound is €1 = £0.787564 and this six-digit figure must always be used when carrying out conversions between the Irish pound and the euro
€1 = £0.787564 an ráta malairte idir an Euro agus an punt Éireannach agus ní mór i gcónaí úsáid a bhaint as an sé fhigiúr seo nuair atá puint Éireannacha le malartú go Euro
There are rules to be followed when converting prices from Irish pounds to euro
Tá rialacha ann a bhaineann le praghasanna Éireannacha a mhalartú go Euro
These are summarised as follows:
Achomair ar na rialacha atá anseo:
• Divide the Irish pound amount by the conversion rate, i.e., by 0.787564
• Roinn na puint Éireannacha faoin ráta malairte, i.e., faoi 0.787564
• Round the resulting euro amount to two decimal places, i.e., to cent
• Déan an figiúr Euro cruinn chuig an dara deachúil, i.e., chuig ceint
• Round down where the third figure after the decimal point is 4 or lower; round up where it is 5 or higher
• Tar anuas nuair is 4 nó níos lú atá sa tríú deachúil agus téigh suas nuair is 5 nó níos mó atá sa tríú deachúil
For example, €3.174 should be rounded down to €3.17 and €6.348 should be rounded up to €6.35
Mar shampla, ba cheart €3.174 a thabhairt anuas go dtí €3.17 agus €6.348 a thabhairt suas go dtí €6.35
